title: Lesson 3: Uniform and Non-Uniform Motion
content:
Imagine two cars on a road. One glides along smoothly, while the other speeds up and slows down. What's the difference?

The secret lies in the rhythm of their movement. One has a steady beat, the other has a changing one. Let's explore this rhythm of motion!

Lesson 3: Uniform and Non-Uniform Motion

The Steady Pace vs. The Stop-and-Go Journey

1. Uniform Motion: The Steady Cruise

An object is in **uniform motion** when it travels **equal distances in equal intervals of time**. No matter how small the time interval you choose, the distance covered is always the same. Think of it as a perfectly steady, constant, and predictable pace.

Example from the textbook: An object travels 5 meters in the first second, 5 more meters in the second second, 5 more in the third, and so on. Its motion is uniform.

2. Non-Uniform Motion: The Everyday Journey

An object is in **non-uniform motion** when it travels **unequal distances in equal intervals of time**. This is the type of motion we see most often. Think of a car in city traffic speeding up, slowing down for a turn, and stopping at a red light. Its pace is always changing.

Example from the textbook: A car moving on a crowded street or a person jogging in a park. Let's imagine a jogging person.

3. How to Spot Uniform vs. Non-Uniform Motion in Data

We can analyze a table of data to determine the type of motion. Let's look at Table 7.1 from the textbook.

Table 7.1: Motion of Objects A and B

Analysis of Object A

Time Interval 1 (9:30 to 9:45): Distance = 20 m - 10 m = 10 m

Time Interval 2 (9:45 to 10:00): Distance = 30 m - 20 m = 10 m

Time Interval 3 (10:00 to 10:15): Distance = 40 m - 30 m = 10 m

Conclusion: Object A covers an equal distance (10 m) in equal time intervals (15 mins). Its motion is UNIFORM.

Analysis of Object B

Time Interval 1 (9:30 to 9:45): Distance = 19 m - 12 m = 7 m

Time Interval 2 (9:45 to 10:00): Distance = 23 m - 19 m = 4 m

Time Interval 3 (10:00 to 10:15): Distance = 35 m - 23 m = 12 m

Conclusion: Object B covers unequal distances (7 m, 4 m, 12 m) in equal time intervals (15 mins). Its motion is NON-UNIFORM.

Lesson 3 Summary: The Rhythm of Motion

UNIFORM MOTION

Equal distances in equal time intervals.

  • Pace: Constant and steady.
  • Example: A car on a clear highway with cruise control on.

NON-UNIFORM MOTION

Unequal distances in equal time intervals.

  • Pace: Always changing (speeding up or slowing down).
  • Example: A person jogging in a crowded park.
questions:
Lesson 3: Questions and Answers

1. What is the definition of uniform motion? Give a simple example.

Definition:

Uniform motion is a type of motion where an object covers **equal distances in equal intervals of time**.

Example:

Imagine a toy car moving along a straight track. If it travels exactly 10 cm every second, its motion is uniform.

Final Answer: Uniform motion is when an object travels equal distances in equal time intervals, like a car on cruise control on a straight, empty highway.

2. What is non-uniform motion? Provide two real-world examples.

Definition:

Non-uniform motion is a type of motion where an object covers **unequal distances in equal intervals of time**.

Examples:

  • A car in city traffic: It speeds up, slows down, and stops, covering different distances every 10 seconds.
  • A person jogging in a park: They might run fast initially, slow down to catch their breath, and then speed up again.

Final Answer: Non-uniform motion occurs when an object covers unequal distances in equal time intervals. Examples include a car in traffic and a jogging person.

3. A ball is rolling on the floor. Its position is recorded every 2 seconds in the table below. Is the motion uniform or non-uniform?

Time (s) 0 2 4 6
Distance (m) 0 8 16 24

Step 1: Check the time intervals.

The time intervals are 0s to 2s, 2s to 4s, and 4s to 6s. Each interval is 2 seconds long, so we are checking against equal intervals of time.

Step 2: Calculate the distance covered in each time interval.

  • Interval 1 (0s to 2s): Distance = 8 m - 0 m = 8 m.
  • Interval 2 (2s to 4s): Distance = 16 m - 8 m = 8 m.
  • Interval 3 (4s to 6s): Distance = 24 m - 16 m = 8 m.

Step 3: Compare the distances.

The ball covers an equal distance (8 m) in each equal time interval (2 s).

Final Answer: The motion is uniform because the ball travels equal distances in equal intervals of time.

4. Look at the data for Object B from Table 7.1 in your textbook. Explain why its motion is non-uniform.

Time9:30 am9:45 am10:00 am10:15 am
Distance (m)12192335

Step 1: Identify the time intervals.

The time intervals are all equal: 9:30 to 9:45 (15 mins), 9:45 to 10:00 (15 mins), and 10:00 to 10:15 (15 mins).

Step 2: Calculate the distance covered in each interval.

  • Interval 1 (9:30 to 9:45): Distance = 19 m - 12 m = 7 m.
  • Interval 2 (9:45 to 10:00): Distance = 23 m - 19 m = 4 m.
  • Interval 3 (10:00 to 10:15): Distance = 35 m - 23 m = 12 m.

Step 3: Compare the distances.

The distances covered (7 m, 4 m, 12 m) are unequal.

Final Answer: The motion of Object B is non-uniform because it covers unequal distances in equal intervals of time.

5. The tip of a second hand on a wall clock moves around the dial. Is this an example of uniform motion?

Analysis:

Let's consider the distance the tip travels. In the first 15 seconds, it travels a quarter of the circle. In the next 15 seconds, it travels another quarter of the circle. The *distance* (the arc length) it covers in any equal time interval is the same.

Final Answer: Yes. The tip of the second hand covers equal distances (arc lengths) in equal intervals of time, so its motion is uniform.

6. A freely falling stone from the top of a building speeds up as it falls. Is its motion uniform or non-uniform? Explain.

Analysis:

The key phrase is "speeds up." This means in the first second of its fall, it will cover a certain distance. In the second second, because it is moving faster, it will cover a greater distance. In the third second, it will cover an even greater distance.

Conclusion:

Since the stone covers unequal distances in equal intervals of time, its motion is non-uniform.

Final Answer: The motion of a freely falling stone is non-uniform because it continuously speeds up, covering larger and larger distances in each successive time interval.

7. Give one example of an object in uniform motion and one in non-uniform motion from your daily commute to school.

Answers will vary, but here is a typical example:

Example of Uniform Motion:

A part of the journey on a long, straight, and empty road where the bus/car maintains a constant speed without any traffic. For a few minutes, it might cover equal distances in equal time intervals.

Example of Non-Uniform Motion:

The bus/car moving through a crowded market or stopping at traffic signals. It constantly starts, stops, speeds up, and slows down, covering very different distances in equal time intervals. This is the more common type of motion.

8. If a car is travelling with uniform motion, what can you say about its speed?

Analysis:

Uniform motion means the car covers equal distances in equal time intervals. The rate at which it covers distance (which is its speed) is therefore not changing.

Final Answer: If a car is in uniform motion, its speed must be constant.

9. A cyclist travels 50 m in the first 10 seconds, and another 50 m in the next 10 seconds. Is their motion definitely uniform?

Analysis:

This is a trick question! While the cyclist covers equal distances (50 m) in equal *large* time intervals (10 s), we don't know what happened *within* those intervals. The cyclist could have gone fast for 5 seconds and then slow for 5 seconds in the first interval, and done the same in the second.

Conclusion:

The definition of uniform motion says the object must cover equal distances in equal time intervals, "no matter how small the time interval". We can't be sure this is true from the given data.

Final Answer: Not necessarily. For motion to be truly uniform, the object must cover equal distances in *any* equal time interval, however small. The cyclist could have changed speed within each 10-second interval.

10. Most objects in our everyday life exhibit which type of motion: uniform or non-uniform? Explain why.

Observation:

Think about walking, running, driving a car, a flying bird, or a rolling ball. In almost all these cases, their speed changes. They start, stop, speed up, and slow down due to forces like friction, air resistance, or the need to change direction.

Conclusion:

Maintaining a perfectly constant pace is very difficult in the real world.

Final Answer: Most objects in everyday life exhibit non-uniform motion because their speed is constantly changing due to various forces and interactions with their surroundings.
exercises:
Lesson 3: Exercises

1. The Elevator's Journey

An elevator starts from the ground floor, speeds up, travels at a constant speed, and then slows down to stop at the 5th floor. Classify the motion during these three phases:

  • Phase 1: When it is just starting and speeding up.
  • Phase 2: When it is travelling between floors at a steady speed.
  • Phase 3: When it is slowing down to stop.
  • Phase 1 (Speeding up): The elevator covers more and more distance each second. This is Non-Uniform Motion.
  • Phase 2 (Steady speed): The elevator covers an equal distance each second. This is Uniform Motion.
  • Phase 3 (Slowing down): The elevator covers less and less distance each second. This is Non-Uniform Motion.

2. Analyze the Data

A bee's flight path is tracked every 5 seconds. Is its motion uniform or non-uniform? Justify your answer.

Time (s) 0 5 10 15
Distance (m) 0 12 19 25

Step 1: Identify the equal time intervals.

The time intervals are 0-5s, 5-10s, and 10-15s. Each is 5 seconds long.

Step 2: Calculate the distance covered in each interval.

  • Interval 1 (0s to 5s): Distance = 12 m - 0 m = 12 m.
  • Interval 2 (5s to 10s): Distance = 19 m - 12 m = 7 m.
  • Interval 3 (10s to 15s): Distance = 25 m - 19 m = 6 m.

Step 3: Compare the distances.

The distances covered (12 m, 7 m, 6 m) are unequal.

Final Answer: The bee's motion is non-uniform because it covers unequal distances in equal intervals of time.

3. Create Your Own Example

Create a simple numerical example (like in the tables above) showing the motion of a cyclist undergoing non-uniform motion over 3 equal time intervals.

There are infinite correct answers. The key is to show unequal distances covered in equal time intervals. Here is one possible example:

Time (s) 0 10 20 30
Distance (m) 0 50 90 140

Justification:

  • In the first 10s, the cyclist travels 50 m.
  • In the second 10s, the cyclist travels 40 m (90-50).
  • In the third 10s, the cyclist travels 50 m (140-90).

Since the distances (50m, 40m, 50m) are unequal, the motion is non-uniform.

4. Visual Analysis

The diagrams below show snapshots of two balls, A and B, taken every 1 second. Which ball is in uniform motion and which is in non-uniform motion?

Ball A

Ball B

  • Ball A: The gap between each position is the same. This means it covers equal distances in equal time intervals. Therefore, Ball A is in uniform motion.
  • Ball B: The gap between positions keeps increasing. This means it covers unequal distances in equal time intervals (it's speeding up). Therefore, Ball B is in non-uniform motion.

5. Odd One Out

From the list below, identify the motion that is different from the others and explain why.

(a) A train starting from a station.

(b) A fan's blades rotating at a constant speed.

(c) A vehicle applying brakes.

(d) An athlete running a 100m race.

Analysis:

  • (a) Train starting: Speed changes from zero to some value (non-uniform).
  • (b) Fan's blades: The tip of the blade covers equal distances in equal time (uniform).
  • (c) Vehicle braking: Speed changes to slow down (non-uniform).
  • (d) Athlete racing: Speed changes from start to finish (non-uniform).

Final Answer: (b) A fan's blades rotating at a constant speed is the odd one out. It is an example of uniform motion, while all the others are examples of non-uniform motion.

6. A Thought Experiment

If an object is in uniform motion, will its speed ever be zero during its journey?

Reasoning:

Uniform motion implies moving at a constant, steady pace. If the speed were to become zero at any point, it means the object stopped. An object that stops and then starts again is changing its speed, which is the definition of non-uniform motion. For the motion to remain uniform, the speed must be constant AND non-zero.

Final Answer: No. If an object is in uniform motion, its speed must be constant and greater than zero throughout the journey.

7. True or False?

"If an object covers 100 km in 2 hours and another 100 km in the next 2 hours, its motion must be uniform."

Analysis:

This statement is tricky. While the average pace is the same over these large 2-hour intervals, we don't know what happened *within* each interval. The object could have sped up and slowed down dramatically within the first 2 hours, and done the same in the next 2 hours. True uniform motion requires the pace to be steady over *any* time interval, no matter how small.

Final Answer: False. The motion is not necessarily uniform. It's possible the object's speed changed within each 2-hour block.
intros:
Lesson 3: Uniform and Non-Uniform Motion

Is the object's motion steady and predictable, or is it changing all the time? Let's explore the rhythm of motion!

Intro 1: The Highway vs. The City Street

Why is driving on a clear highway so different from driving in a crowded city?

On an open highway, a car can travel at a steady pace. If it covers 20 meters every second, it’s a smooth, predictable journey. This is called **uniform motion**: an object covers equal distances in equal intervals of time. It's a constant, unchanging rhythm of movement.

In a busy city, the car is constantly speeding up, slowing down, and stopping for traffic. In one second it might travel 10 meters, the next second it might travel only 2 meters, and then it might stop completely. This is **non-uniform motion**: an object covers unequal distances in equal intervals of time. This is the stop-and-go, unpredictable motion we see most often in real life.

Uniform motion is a steady cruise. Non-uniform motion is a traffic jam.

Intro 2: The Dripping Faucet

How can a leaky faucet teach us about motion?

Imagine a faucet with a steady *drip... drip... drip...*. Each drop falls after the same amount of time. If you were tracking an object moving in this way—covering a set distance with every "drip"—it would be in **uniform motion**. The timing is perfectly regular and predictable.

Now imagine a faulty faucet that goes *drip..drip...drip-drip...drip*. The time between the drops is random and uneven. If an object moved like this, covering a set distance with each random drip, it would be in **non-uniform motion**. The movement is jerky, irregular, and unpredictable. Most motion in the real world is like this second faucet.

Uniform motion has a steady beat; non-uniform motion has a broken rhythm.

Intro 3: The Tortoise and the Hare

In the famous fable, who demonstrated uniform motion?

The tortoise moved slowly but steadily. It covered the same small distance in every minute of the race. Its motion was predictable and constant. This is a perfect example of **uniform motion**.

The hare, on the other hand, was all over the place. It ran extremely fast at the beginning, covering a large distance in a short time. Then it stopped completely to take a nap, covering zero distance for a long time. Finally, it dashed again. Its movement was inconsistent and changed constantly. This is **non-uniform motion**.

Uniform motion wins the race with consistency, not speed.

Intro 4: The Music Beat

How is motion like a song's rhythm?

Think of a simple, steady metronome: *tick, tock, tick, tock*. Each tick happens after the exact same amount of time. If a dancer takes one step forward with every tick, they are in **uniform motion**. Their movement is even and easy to predict.

Now, think of a complex drum solo: *boom, ba-da-boom, tap, BOOM*. The beats are varied and come at different intervals. If a dancer tried to match this rhythm, their movement would be fast, then slow, then fast again. This is **non-uniform motion**. It's dynamic and always changing, just like a car in traffic or a person jogging in a park.

Uniform motion is the baseline, non-uniform motion is the solo.

Intro 5: The Marathon Runner

Does a marathon runner maintain the same pace for the whole race?

In an ideal world, a runner might want to maintain a perfectly steady pace, covering each kilometre in exactly the same amount of time. This would be **uniform motion**. It's the most efficient way to run, but very hard to achieve.

In reality, a runner starts fast, might slow down on a hill, speed up on a flat stretch, and get tired near the end. They cover unequal distances in equal time intervals. For example, they might run the first 10 km in 50 minutes, the next 10 km in 55 minutes, and the next in 60 minutes as they get tired. This is **non-uniform motion**, and it's how almost all real-world journeys happen.

Uniform motion is the goal; non-uniform motion is the reality.
summary:
Lesson 3 Summary

Uniform & Non-Uniform Motion

Understanding the "rhythm" of movement is key. Is an object's motion steady and predictable, or is it changing? This lesson breaks down the two fundamental types of motion you'll encounter.

Uniform Motion

"A Steady, Constant Pace"

An object is in uniform motion when it travels equal distances in equal intervals of time, no matter how small the time intervals are.

  • ➤
    Key Feature: The object's speed is constant.
  • ➤
    Example: A car on cruise control on a perfectly straight and empty highway.

Non-Uniform Motion

"A Changing, Real-World Pace"

An object is in non-uniform motion when it travels unequal distances in equal intervals of time.

  • ➤
    Key Feature: The object's speed is changing. It is either speeding up or slowing down.
  • ➤
    Example: A car moving through city traffic, a person jogging in a park, a freely falling stone.

Visualizing the Motion: Two Cars, Two Journeys

Car A: Uniform Motion (Constant Speed)

Notice the equal distance (20m) covered in each second.

Car B: Non-Uniform Motion (Changing Speed)

Notice the unequal distances covered in each second.

Data Analysis: A Tale of Two Objects

Let's look at the data for two objects, A and B, from the textbook (Table 7.1). This shows the difference clearly.

Time Distance by A (m) Distance by B (m)
9:30 am1012
9:45 am20 (+10)19 (+7)
10:00 am30 (+10)23 (+4)
10:15 am40 (+10)35 (+12)

Object A travels a consistent 10m every 15 minutes (Uniform Motion). Object B travels varying distances (Non-Uniform Motion).

Exam Quick Facts

  • Uniform Motion: Equal distances in equal time intervals. Think 'constant speed'.
  • Non-Uniform Motion: Unequal distances in equal time intervals. Think 'changing speed' (accelerating or decelerating).
  • Most motion in everyday life (driving, walking, running) is non-uniform.
